chapter.title: Installation
chapter.para: What you need to get WASP installed.

section.title: Getting the WASP System Source Code from GitHub
section.para:
Make sure you have Git on your server (obtain from http://git-scm.com) and obtain the latest WASP System code from https://github.com/WASP-System.
Please make sure you understand the importance of line endings in Git and adjust your setting accordingly: http://help.github.com/articles/dealing-with-line-endings

After cloning the WASP System source code, you’ll notice the project contains many folders. Most of these represent modules of the system, wrapped up into individual Maven projects:
dbContains database initialization files
wasp-parentHosts a parent.pom that defines common dependencies and versions required by other components. Maven Project.
wasp-webThe WASP System webapp. Maven/Spring project. Builds a war file for Tomcat7 deployment.
wasp-coreSpring component containing core code. Maven/Spring project. Builds a jar.
wasp-configlocal configuration e.g. database and email sever details etc. Maven/Spring project. Builds a jar.
wasp-execSpring component that runs WASP System task management flows and pipeline flows. Maven/Spring project. Builds a jar.
wasp-pluginsContains subfolders which contain modular extensions, each is a Maven/Spring project that builds a jar.
wasp-tomcat-classloaderExtends WebappClassLoader to allow loading of classes from the waspPlugins folder in the Tomcat base folder. Maven project. Builds a jar
wasp-cliUsed to run wasp analysis jobs from the command line. Maven/Spring project. Builds a jar.
wasp-docThis DocBooks documentation. Builds documentation

listitem.para: Download the latest versions of the following software packages and install according to the provider’s instructions:
Apache Tomcat7 (http://tomcat.apache.org)
Apache Maven3(http://maven.apache.org)
Apache Ant (http://ant.apache.org)
Oracle Java SE 6 (http://www.oracle.com)
MySQL Community Server (http://www.mysql.com/downloads/mysql)
Add environment variables to your user profile and set the values to the paths of the installations above:
Then set the PATH environment variable to point to the relevant binaries.
E.g. in a typical Linux setup using bash, your .bashrc file should contain something similar to this:
listitem.programlisting: export ANT_HOME=/opt/ant export JAVA_HOME=/usr/java/latest export CATALINA_HOME=/usr/local/tomcat/tomcat/current export MAVEN_HOME=/opt/maven/current export PATH=$JAVA_HOME/bin:$ANT_HOME/bin:$MAVEN_HOME/bin:$PATH

Open $CATALINA_HOME/conf/tomcat-users.xml using your favorite editor and add the following (replacing placeholders ‘myGuiPass’ and ‘myScriptPass’ with your own choice of passwords):
listitem.programlisting: </tomcat-users> <role rolename="manager-gui"/> <user username="tomcat" password="myGuiPass" roles="manager-gui"/> <role rolename="manager-script"/> <user username="tomcat-script" password="myScriptPass" roles="manager-script"/> </tomcat-users>
listitem.para: The manager-script account is used to deploy The WASP System using Maven. The managergui account can be used to manage your tomcat installation at http://localhost:8080/manager. To create a startup launch daemon:
Type the following at the command line:
listitem.programlisting: $ cd $CATALINA_HOME/bin $ tar xvfz commons-daemon-native.tar.gz $ cd commons-daemon-1.0.x-native-src/unix $ ./configure $ make $ cp jsvc ../..

listitem.para:
Using your favorite editor and sudo, create the following file /etc/init.d/tomcat7 then paste in the following:
Replace the values of the variables under # local config section at the top with values relevant to your setup
At the command line run: $ chkconfig --add tomcat7
At the command line run $ sudo /etc/init.d/tomcat7 start to start tomcat. You should see a welcome page at http://localhost:8080 if all went well.

Clone the wasp repository using git clone url. It may be useful to set an environment variable in your .bash_profile (or .bashrc) to point to this installation. For the remainder of this section it is assumed you have created such a variable and called it WASP_HOME.

Install the core WASP components:

Check to see that wasp-tomcat-classloader-x.x.x-SNAPSHOT.jar has been copied into the $CATALINA_HOME/lib folder. If not (due to a permissions issue) you should do this manually: $ sudo cp $WASP_HOME/wasp-tomcat-classloader/target/wasp-tomcat-classloader-?.?.?-SNAPSHOT.jar $CATALINA_HOME/lib
Install the provided plugins:

para.userinput: $ for x in `ls -d $WASP_HOME/wasp-plugins/*`;do cd $x; mvn -Dcatalina.home=$CATALINA_HOME clean install;done

listitem.para: If the jars failed to be copied into the $CATALINA_HOME/waspPlugins folder, make sure your user has permission to write to this folder and try again.
Deploy the WASP System webapp: $ mvn tomcat:deploy
If this fails you should check that Tomcat7 Setup Step 2, above, was completed properly.
listitem.note: The commands $ mvn tomcat:undeploy and $ mvn tomcat:redeploy are also useful and selfexplanatory.

listitem.para: Goto localhost:8080/wasp. If you see the login page you have set up the webapp properly.

The DocBook documentation (docbook.sourceforge.net) can be built by running the following commands:
listitem.programlisting: $ cd $WASP_HOME/wasp-doc $ mvn clean install docbkx:generate-html docbkx:generate-pdf $ cp -R $WASP_HOME/wasp-doc/src/docbkx/content/figures $WASP_HOME/wasp-doc/target/docbkx/html

listitem.para: Javadoc can be generated by running $ mvn javadoc:javadoc in any component parent folder, e.g. WASP_HOME/wasp-web (for the WASP SYSTEM webapp) or $WASP_HOME/wasp-core (for the core code). The documentation can then be found in target/apidocs folder under the component parent folder.
